name: 3,3-dimethylhexane
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.

name: 3,3-dimethylhexane
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The target compound, 3,3-dimethylhexane, is an alkane with a basic carbon chain. The basic unit for comparison is hexane, which has a melting point of -95°C. Each additional methyl branch typically increases the melting point due to increased steric hindrance and better packing efficiency, approximatively +5°C per methyl group. In 3,3-dimethylhexane, there are two additional methyl groups compared to hexane.

name: 3,3-dimethylhexane
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The target compound, 3,3-dimethylhexane, is an alkane with a basic carbon chain. The basic unit for comparison is hexane, which has a melting point of -95°C. Each additional methyl branch typically increases the melting point by making the molecule more compact and symmetrical, which promotes better packing in the solid state; however, excessive branching can sometimes decrease the melting point if it disrupts the packing efficiency. The effect of one additional methyl group in such branched alkanes can be estimated to raise the melting point by about +3-5°C per methyl group due to steric hindrance offset by increased symmetry. In 3,3-dimethylhexane, there are two additional methyl groups compared to hexane, resulting in an increase.

name: 3,3-dimethylhexane
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The basic unit, hexane has a melting point of around -95°C. Each methyl group branching generally raises the melting point due to increased steric hindrance, making the molecule more spherical which strengthens instantaneous-dipole induced-dipole interactions. In this case, there are two additional methyl groups attached to the same carbon. Estimating the increase as +15°C per additional branching, we get +30°C total for the two methyl groups.

name: 3,3-dimethylhexane
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The basic unit, hexane has a melting point of around -95°C. Methyl group branching typically raises the melting point as it introduces steric hindrance, and tends to make the molecule more spherical, thus improving the packing in solid state which can lead to higher melting points. However, the influence of each methyl group can't be simplified to such a high increment as there are diminishing returns due to the increasing bulk. A more cautious estimate might be around +5°C per additional methyl group. Therefore, two extra methyl groups would increase the melting point by approximately +10°C.

name: 3,3-dimethylhexane
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The basic unit here is n-hexane, which normally has a melting point of around -95°C. When looking at the effects of functional groups, the two methyl groups on the third carbon could affect the melting point in several ways. Firstly, branching tends to decrease the melting point of an alkane because it makes the molecule less able to pack efficiently in a solid state, which in turn weakens the intermolecular forces. This effect might decrease the melting point roughly by about 20°C to 30°C per methyl group compared to n-hexane. There is a cumulative effect, but the second methyl group may not decrease it as much as the first one did since after a certain level of branching, additional groups have a diminished effect. Therefore, a rough estimate might be a decrease of about 40°C to 50°C from n-hexane’s melting point due to both methyl groups.

name: 3,3-dimethylhexane
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The basic unit here is n-hexane, which normally has a melting point of around -95°C. Branching with methyl groups generally decreases the melting point of alkanes due to less efficient packing in the solid state, weakening intermolecular forces. The effect of one methyl group could be estimated to decrease the melting point by about 10°C to 15°C. With two methyl groups, the compound has enhanced branching, which may further decrease the melting point, although the effect of the second group is less pronounced than the first due to diminishing returns in the impact of additional branching. Hence, an approximate total decrease of 20°C to 30°C from n-hexane's melting point might be anticipated for 3,3-dimethylhexane.
